citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Center for Coastal and Watershed Studies and Tampa Water District Office
citeinfo.title: USGS Surface water Advance Station Data
Gulf of Mexico Integrated Science - Tampa Bay Pilot Study Project number 7242-01

descript.abstract: The USGS Water Resources Division, along with the Tampa Bay Study Program has established two new surface water advance stations to gather water data within Tampa Bay. One station (Hillsborough Bay Station 1 - ID 275030082274600) will measure water velocity, water level, near-bottom specific conductance and near-bottom water temperature; the second station (Bishop Harbor - ID 273629082341400) will collected those variables previously listed as well as discharge at the mouth of Bishop Harbor. Water level, water velocity, and near-bottom water temperature and specific conductance are measured every 15 minutes. Water level for the Hillsborough Bay station is an eight-second average reading measured at the quarter hour. Water level for the Bishop Harbor station is a ten-second average reading measured at the quarter hour. Water velocity for both stations is a four-minute average that begins two minutes before the quarter hour and ends two minutes after the quarter hour. Velocity time for both stations is reported on the quarter-hour. Near-bottom temperature and specific conductance are ten-second averages. The Bishop Harbor station measurement starts on the quarter hour; for the Hillsborough Bay station, the measurement begins 10 seconds after the quarter hour.
descript.purpose: To collect real-time water data for the Tampa Bay Study Program at two newly established sites. For the Bishop Harbor station - collection of hydrologic data to be used to estimate residence time and hydrodynamic characteristics for the subembayment. For the Hillsborough Bay station - collection of hydrologic data to be used to refine circulation patterns and residence time for the Bay.

idinfo.accconst: Any downloading and use of these data signifies a user's agreement to comprehension and compliance of the USGS Standard Disclaimer. Insure all portions of metadata are read and clearly understood before using these data in order to protect both user and USGS interests. See section 6.3 Distribution Liability.
idinfo.useconst: Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey Tampa Bay Study Program as a data source would be appreciated in products developed from these data, and such acknowledgement as is standard for citation and legal practices for data source is expected by users of this data. Sharing new data layers developed directly from these data would also be appreciated by USGS staff. Users should be aware of that comparisons with other data sets for the same area from other time periods may be inaccurate due to inconsistencies resulting from changes in photo interpretation, mapping conventions, and digital processes over time. These data are not legal documents and are not to be used as such.
idinfo.native: USGS NWIS Automated Data Processing System

citeinfo.origin: US Geological Survey, Water Resources Division
citeinfo.title: National Water Information System

attracc.attraccr: Accuracy of the measured attributes is dependent on the equipment used to collect the data. For water velocity, the expected accuracy is plus or minus 0.05 feet per second. For water level, the expected accuracy is plus or minus 0.02 feet. For specific conductance, the expected accuracy is less than 3% of the reading. For water temperature, the expected accuracy is 0.2 degrees Centigrade. For the discharge attribute for the Bishop Harbor station, the expected accuracy has not been established.

dataqual.logic: All procedures have been followed for the establishment of the two surface water stations.
dataqual.complete: There are no expected gaps in the real time data, barring unforseen complications with equipment or environmental conditions.

procstep.procdesc: Field installation - For the Hillsborough Bay station, a Campbell Scientific CR10X data logger and SM4M storage module, battery, and sensor wiring are housed in a fiberglass shelter attached to an US Coast Guard Aid to Navigation. Additional equipment consists of a vented pressure sensor (H-310 or equivalent) in a 4 inch PVC stilling weel, a SonTek 1.5 Megahertz ADP vertically oriented velocity profiler moored to the bay bottom approximately 100 feet SSE of the range-markers southwest-most piling, and a temperature/specific conductance sensor (YSI-600-BCR-C-T) positioned one foot above the bottom inside a perforated 4 inch PVC well. For the Bishop Harbor station, a Campbell Scientific CR10X data logger and SM4M storage module, battery, sensor wiring were housed in two fiberglass shelters attached to a 8 inch diameter wood piling. Additional equipment consists of a vented pressure sensor (KPSI 500) in a 4 inch PVC well, a SonTek 3.0 Megahertz Argonaut-XR vertically oriented current sensor moored to the harbor bottom approximately 170 feet SSE of the equipment piling, and a temperature/specific conductance sensor (YSI-600-BCR-C-T) positioned approximately one foot above the bottom inside a perforated 4 inch PVC well attached to the 8 inch diameter wood piling.

Data Processing - MatLab with signal processing and statistics toolboxes is used to analyze and process data. The data gathered are then stored and edited in the USGS NWIS Automated Data Processing System (ADAPS).

spdoinfo.indspref: For the Bishop Harbor station, SE,NW, NW quarter of Sec. 14, T 33 S., R. 17 E. Station gage is approximately 150 feet from left bank of the harbor mouth. For the Hillsborough Bay station, east of Sec. 26, T. 30 S., R. 18 E. Station gage is located on the USCG Aid to Navigation, Alafia River Rear Range Light LLNR 23245.

overview.eaover: For the Hillsborough Bay station, the attributes measured by the equipment consist of water velocity (in feet per second), water level (in feet), specific conductance (microSiemens per centimeter at 25 degrees C), and water temperature (in Centigrade). For the Bishop Harbor station, the attributes measured by the equipment consist of water velocity (in feet per second), water level (in feet), specific conductance (microSiemens per centimeter at 25 degrees C), water temperature (in Centigrade), and discharge (cubic feet per second).

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data or any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data.
